member.name: T:GamePersistence
member.para: Handles saving and loading of SFS files and <ref refid='class_flight_state' kindref='compound'>FlightState</ref> objects. Use this as an entry point for all saving/loading-related things.
member.remarks: - Contains some functions you can call to save the game state to a persistence file, or load the game state from a persistence file.

member.name: M:GamePersistence.LoadGame(string,string,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.para: Loads a game state from the given file. Does not actually apply the loaded game state to the scene. Use <ref refid='class_game_1a82a7f7d1923d383f52c056cc60eae5d2' kindref='member'>Game.Start()</ref> or <ref refid='class_game_1a551bc102faffd4f690dbf587005f1307' kindref='member'>Game.Load()</ref> for that.

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>filename</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> <parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>saveFolder</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> <parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>nullIfIncompatible</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>return null if the game turns out to be incompatible (NOTE: most members will be null for incompatible games)
member.remarks: </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> <parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>suppressIncompatibleMessage</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>skip displaying a popup dialog if the game is incompatible</para></parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist> <simplesect kind='return'><para></para></simplesect> </para> - filename without extension

member.name: M:GamePersistence.SaveGame(string,string,SaveMode)
member.para: Updates and saves the game state to the given file name on the given save folder.
member.remarks:
- Creates a persistence file containing the current game state.
SaveGame(string, string, SaveMode) calls SaveGame(HighLogic.CurrentGame.Updated(), string, string, SaveMode) (or creates CurrentGame if it doesn't exist).
member.param: The name of the persistence file to create (".sfs" will be appended automatically to the file name).
The folder in which to create the save file. Use HighLogic.SaveFolder to acquire the default one for the current game.
Whether to overwrite, append, or abort if the given file already exists.
member.returns: Returns the filename on success. Returns an empty string when the file already exists and SaveMode.ABORT is used.

member.name: M:GamePersistence.SaveGame(Game,string,string,SaveMode)
member.para: Saves an SFS file from the given <ref refid='class_game' kindref='compound'>Game</ref> object with the supplied filename
member.remarks: - For creating a savegame at the space center, simply use SaveGame(string, string, SaveMode) instead. For quicksaves call Updated() on CurrentGame to get a Game, then reset that Game's startScene to FLIGHT, and then call SaveGame(Game, string, string, SaveMode).
member.param: The game for which you want to create a save file.
The name of the persistence file to create (".sfs" will be appended to the file name).
The folder in which to create the save file. Use HighLogic.SaveFolder to acquire the default one for the current game.
Whether to overwrite, append, or abort if the given file already exists.
member.returns: Returns the filename on success. Returns an empty string when the file already exists and SaveMode.ABORT is used.

member.name: M:GamePersistence.SaveGame(GameBackup,string,string,SaveMode)
member.para: Saves an SFS file from the given <ref refid='class_game' kindref='compound'>Game</ref> object with the supplied filename

</simplesect>

</simplesect>

member.name: T:KFSMEvent
member.summary: A KFSMEvent represents a possible transition between two KFSMStates in a KerbalFSM finite state machine.

member.name: F:KFSMEvent.GoToStateOnEvent
member.summary: Which state to transition to when this event is triggered.

member.name: F:KFSMEvent.name
member.summary: The name of the event.

member.name: F:KFSMEvent.OnCheckCondition
member.summary: You can assign to this field a delegate that takes a KFSMState (the current state) and returns a bool. The function will be called each frame and if it returns true, the event is triggered.

member.name: F:KFSMEvent.OnEvent
member.summary: You can assign a delegate to this field, and the delegate will be run when the event is triggered.

member.name: F:KFSMEvent.updateMode
member.summary: Specifies when OnCheckCondition should be checked?

member.name: M:KFSMEvent.IsValid(KFSMState)
member.summary: Whether this event can be triggered when the state machine is in the given state. Events must be added to states through KerbalFSM.AddEvent before they can be triggered, and they can only be triggered when the machine is in one of the states to which they have been added.
member.param: The state to check.
member.returns: Whether the event can be triggered from the given state.

member.name: M:KFSMEvent.#ctor(string)
member.summary: Creates a new KFSMEvent
member.param: The name of the event.

member.name: T:KFSMState
member.summary: Represents a state in a KerbalFSM finite state machine.

member.name: F:KFSMState.name
member.summary: The name of this state.

member.name: F:KFSMState.OnEnter
member.summary: You can assign to this field a delegate that takes a KFSMState (which will be this state). The delegate will be called when the state machine enters this state.

member.name: F:KFSMState.OnFixedUpdate
member.summary: You can assign a delegate to this field, and the delegate will be called during each FixedUpdate while the state machine is in this state.

member.name: F:KFSMState.OnLateUpdate
member.summary: You can assign a delegate to this field, and the delegate will be called during each LateUpdate while the state machine is in this state.

member.name: F:KFSMState.OnLeave
member.summary: You can assign to this field a delegate that takes a KFSMState. The delegate will be called when the state machine leaves this state, and the argument passed to the delegate will be the new state that the machine is transitioning to.

member.name: F:KFSMState.OnUpdate
member.summary: You can assign a delegate to this field, and the delegate will be call during each Update while the state machine is in this state.

member.name: P:KFSMState.StateEvents
member.summary: The set of events that are valid for this state (i.e., the possible transitions from this state).

member.name: M:KFSMState.AddEvent(KFSMEvent)
member.summary: Add an event (possible transition) to this state.
member.param: The event to add.

member.name: M:KFSMState.IsValid(KFSMEvent)
member.summary: Whether the given event can be triggered from this state. An event must be added to a state before it can be triggered from that state.
member.param: The event to check.
member.returns: Whether the event can be triggered from this state.

member.name: M:KFSMState.#ctor(string)
member.summary: Create a new KFSMState with a given name.
member.param: The name of the new state.

member.name: T:KSP.IO.PluginConfiguration
member.para: Acts as a proxy between plugins and the filesystem so plugins can't go and mess with stuff outside of <ref refid='namespace_k_s_p' kindref='compound'>KSP</ref>'s install dir. Saves as an XML file in PluginData/assemblyname[/flightname]/config.xml.
member.remarks: - From N3X15: PluginConfiguration was something I threw together a while ago to try and improve settings serialization. The INI files we were using just couldn't cope with newlines and had all sorts of horrible workarounds. Instead of INI files, it writes structured XML files that look like this:

para.code: <config> <int name="int"\>4</int> <long name="long">45</long> <short name="short">4</short> <byte name="byte">255</byte> <bool name="bool">1</bool> <vector3 name="vector3"> <x>0</x> <y>1</y> <z>2</z> </vector3> <vector3d name="vector3d"> <x>0</x> <y>1</y> <z>2.05</z> </vector3d> <string name="string">string</string> </config>

member.para: Despite looking a bit messy, it's actually a lot easier to use and doesn't have as many drawbacks as INI files. Newlines are preserved, and most importantly, types are also preserved. Oh, and it's UTF-8 encoded, so internationalization won't be as much as a problem, theoretically. Here's how to use it:

para.code: PluginConfiguration cfg = PluginConfiguration.CreateForType<MyCoolModule>(); cfg["a string"] = "I love KSP!"; cfg["another setting"] = new Vector3d(0,1,2); cfg.save(); // Later... cfg.load(); settingAString = cfg.GetValue<string>("a string"); settingAVector = cfg.GetValue<Vector3d>("another setting");

member.name: M:KSP.UI.Screens.ApplicationLauncher.AddModApplication(RUIToggleButton.OnTrue,RUIToggleButton.OnFalse,RUIToggleButton.OnHover,RUIToggleButton.OnHoverOut,RUIToggleButton.OnEnable,RUIToggleButton.OnDisable,ApplicationLauncher.AppScenes,PackedSprite)
member.summary: Add a MOD(3rd party) application to the Application Launcher. Use ApplicationLauncherButton.VisibleInScenes to set where the button should be displayed. Note that the application launcher is destroyed when the player exits to the main menu. If the player then loads up a new save the application launcher will be recreated and you will have to re-add your button. Register for GameEvents.onGUIApplicationLauncherDestroyed and GameEvents.onGUIApplicationLauncherReady to detect when the application launcher has been destroyed and when it has been re-created.
member.param: Callback for when the button is toggeled on
Callback for when the button is toggeled off
Callback for when the mouse is hovering over the button
Callback for when the mouse hoveris off the button
Callback for when the button is shown or enabled by the application launcher
Callback for when the button is hidden or disabled by the application launcher
The "scenes" this button will be visible in. For example VisibleInScenes = ApplicationLauncher.AppScenes.FLIGHT | ApplicationLauncher.AppScenes.MAPVIEW;
The 38x38 PackedSprite animation to use for the button icon. Use ApplicationLauncherButton.PlayAnim() to play the animation.

member.name: M:KSP.UI.Screens.Flight.KerbalPortraitGallery.RegisterActiveCrew(Kerbal)
member.summary: Register a Kerbal crewmember to the Portrait Gallery. Beware this will duplicate portraits if the crewmember is already in the list. The list itself cannot be accessed as it is a private list. You can call UnRegisterActiveCrew before calling this. But that kind of defeats the purpose. The best bet is to attach to the portraitPrefab instance and build your own list. If you unregistered the kerbal previously and called kerbal.SetVisibleInPortrait(false) and set kerbal.inPart to null that you have to reverse this and set their inPart and SetVisibleInPortrait(true) before calling this method.

member.name: M:KSP.UI.Screens.Flight.KerbalPortraitGallery.UnregisterActiveCrew(Kerbal)
member.summary: UnRegister a Kerbal crewmember to the Portrait Gallery. They will respawn a portrait though unless you set the kerbal.inPart to null and set the kerbal.SetVisibleInPortrait(false) first. member.name: T:KSPAddon
member.summary: Apply this attribute to a class that derives from MonoBehaviour to have KSP automatically start up your addon at a specified time. At the time specified by the "startup" argument KSP will create a new GameObject and attach your MonoBehaviour to it. You can then implement the Unity event functions like Start(), Update(), etc.

member.name: F:KSPAddon.once
member.summary: Whether KSP should start up your addon just once per game session, or every time the startup time is reached. If you want your addon to persist forever, even through scene changes, after being started once, set once to true. call DontDestroyOnLoad(this) in your Start() function.

member.name: F:KSPAddon.startup
member.summary: When this addon should be started.

member.name: M:KSPAddon.#ctor(KSPAddon+Startup,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: When this addon should be started

Whether KSP should start up your addon just once per game session, or every time the startup time is reached. If you want your addon to persist forever, even through scene changes, after being started once, set once to true. call DontDestroyOnLoad(this) in your Start() function.

member.name: T:KSPAssembly
member.summary: This attribute and the KSPAssemblyDependency attribute can be used to ensure that plugin assemblies are loaded in the right order. Suppose Mod A depends on mod B, which is currently at version 2.6. Mod B should add the following line to the end of Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs:
member.remarks: where "ModBName" is the name of Mod B (Mod B's .dll?). Replace 2 and 6 with the major and minor version of Mod B. Then Mod A should add the following line to the end of Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs:
This will tell KSP that Mod A depends on version 2.6 of Mod B, and ensure the the assemblies get loaded in the proper order.

member.name: T:KSPEvent
member.para: Tells the compiler that this method is an action and allows you to set up the <ref refid='namespace_k_s_p' kindref='compound'>KSP</ref> specific stuff. ** REQUIRED BY ALL ACTION METHODS **
member.remarks: - Apply this attribute to a function in a PartModule to make it callable by the player via the right click menu of the part, or from other plugin code via Part.SendEvent. It seems like this attribute is NOT refreshed on parts already in flight when you rebuild your module DLL! You need to launch a new ship with your part.

member.name: T:KSPField
member.para: Attribute applied to fields to make them persistant or available to the part action GUI

Automatic persistance can only be applied to types which implement the <ref refid='interface_i_config_node' kindref='compound'>IConfigNode</ref> interface or one of the following.. string, bool, int, float, Vector2, Vector3, Vector4 or Quaternion

T:Krakensbane
member.summary: The physics simulation has problems if vessels move too fast relative to the underlying reference frame used by the simulation, or get too far from the origin of the coordinate system. Krakensbane shifts the reference frame origin and velocity so that the active vessel is always near the origin of, and moving slowly with respect to, the underlying coordinate system used by the physics simulation.

member.name: M:Krakensbane.AddExcess(Vector3d)
member.para: Adds the excess velocity to the frame velocity and subtracts the excess from all loaded offrails vessels/physobjects

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>vel</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist>

member.name: M:Krakensbane.FixedUpdate
member.para: Here we determine if we can engage <ref refid='class_krakensbane' kindref='compound'>Krakensbane</ref> (and signal <ref refid='class_floating_origin' kindref='compound'>FloatingOrigin</ref> whether it can engage, too). If we need to disengage <ref refid='class_krakensbane' kindref='compound'>Krakensbane</ref>, we zero the frame velocity and reapply it to everything. Finally if we have frame velocity, we signal <ref refid='class_floating_origin' kindref='compound'>FloatingOrigin</ref> how much additional offset to apply to things outside the <ref refid='class_krakensbane' kindref='compound'>Krakensbane</ref> frame.

member.name: M:Krakensbane.setOffset(Vector3d)
member.summary: Moves all vessels not on rails by the given position offset. This will usually only affect the active vessel, unless there are other vessels nearby. The offset can be very large and the vessels will not break, unlike for Vessel.SetPosition.

member.name: M:Krakensbane.Zero
member.para: Zeroes the frame velocity and applies the frame velocity back to all loaded offrails vessels and physobjects

member.name: M:Krakensbane.AddFrameVelocity(Vector3d)
member.para: Directly sets additional frame velocity. Notably used when the active vessel comes off rails so <ref refid='class_krakensbane' kindref='compound'>Krakensbane</ref> is engaged before a frame of imprecise PhysX, since vessels come off rails in Update and otherwise at the start of the next fixed frame the RB velocities would be high (and therefore imprecise).

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>vel</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist>

member.para: Returns the velocity of the <ref refid='class_krakensbane' kindref='compound'>Krakensbane</ref> velocity frame.

<simplesect kind='return'>
</simplesect>
member.remarks: - Returns the velocity of the Krakensbane velocity frame.

<simplesect kind='return'>

member.remarks: - Returns the velocity of the Krakensbane velocity frame as a single-precision vector.

member.name: F:ManeuverNode.DeltaV
member.summary: The delta-V of the burn represented by this maneuver node, in m/s. NOTE: maneuver nodes use a special coordinate system for delta-V. The x-component of DeltaV represents the delta-V in the radial-plus direction. The y-component of DeltaV represents the delta-V in the normal-minus direction. The z-component of DeltaV represents the delta-V in the prograde direction.

member.name: T:ModuleAblator
member.summary: A PartModule that lets a part cool its skin by consuming a resource through pyrolysis. For example, ablative heatshields are implemented with this module. Attention: this module may override some heat conduction behavior (see reentryConductivity).

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.ablationTempThresh
member.para: Minimum temperature for ablation to start
member.remarks: - Skin temperature (in Kelvin) at which ablation begins. This is merely a cutoff; it doesn't reposition the zero point of the calculation. If you set this value very high, you'll see ablation rate instantly jump from zero to a high value as the temperature passes this threshold.

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.ablativeResource
member.para: Name of the Ablative Resource
member.remarks: - Which resource is consumed by the ablation process. Yes, you can put any resource here that is present in the part, for hilarious results... but you probably want to set it to "Ablator".

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.charMax
member.summary: How dark the charring effect on a part that has experienced ablation can get at most. Between 0 and 1, should be higher than or equal to charMin.

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.charMin
member.summary: How darkly charred a part with ModuleAblator starts out, even without prior use. Between 0 and 1, should be lower than or equal to charMax.

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.charModuleName
member.para: The <ref refid='interface_i_scalar_module' kindref='compound'>IScalarModule</ref> name linked to the Ablator. Must be on the same part.

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.lossConst
member.para: Constant to tune ablator loss
member.remarks: - A constant that governs the rate at which ablation happens. Modified by lossExp. Usually positive and very small (one digit).

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.lossExp
member.para: The "scale height" for ablator loss
member.remarks: - An exponent that governs the rate at which ablation happens. Modifies lossConst. Usually negative and quite large (four digits).

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.nominalAmountRecip
member.para: protected fields

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.origConductivity
member.para: we'll store the part's original conductivity here

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.pyrolysisLoss
member.para: actual per-tonne flux

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.pyrolysisLossFactor
member.para: Factor to the ablator's specific heat to use for the pyrolysis flux

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.reentryConductivity
member.para: When our bottom is unoccluded, assume reentry and lower conductivity
member.remarks: - Governs the internal<->internal heat conduction behavior of a part with ModuleAblator while the part's bottom node is unoccupied. Note that this *hard overrides* all other internals based heat conduction fields, such as heatConductivity or bulkheadProfiles - at all times, not just during actual reentry! (Beware if you try to use ModuleAblator to make ablatively cooled rocket engines.) It doesn't affect skin<->skin conduction between parts, or the part's own skin<->internal heat exchange. Default internal heat conductivity in KSP is 0.12, smaller conducts less, larger conducts more.

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.useChar
member.para: If true (default) will Char (burn) the IscalarModule (defined in CharModuleName) off as the ablator burns off.

member.name: F:ModuleAblator.useNode
member.para: Do we use the drag cube area check or do we use a node open/attached check?

member.name: M:ModuleAblator.FixedUpdate
member.para: < Set conductivity based on whether stuff is occluding our bottom. If not, then we assume
< in units. Note we're using maxAmount now, for consistent decrease.
< clamp
< get loss in kg

member.name: F:ModuleDataTransmitter.xmitIncomplete
member.summary: This flag determine the behaviour in case an individual ScienceData transmission is interrupted for lack of requiredResource. If this is set to true, the partial data transmitted is credited in the science system and the ScienceData lost. If this is set to false, no data is credited in the science system and the ScienceData is returned to the first ModuleScienceContainer with space available in the vessel.

member.name: T:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel
member.summary: Implement solar panel mechanics.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel._distMult
member.summary: Used internally. This is an implementation detail that somehow got exposed to the public API. Do not change nor rely on its value.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel._efficMult
member.summary: Used internally. This is an implementation detail that somehow got exposed to the public API. Do not change nor rely on its value.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel._flowRate
member.summary: Used internally. This is an implementation detail that somehow got exposed to the public API. Do not change nor rely on its value.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.chargeRate
member.summary: The ElectricCharge per second this panel will generate when in direct sunlight, perfectly aligned with the sun direction and at a distance from the Sun center equal to the major axis of the home body.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.hit
member.para: for debugging
member.remarks: - Store the results of the last raycast from the solar panel position toward the Sun.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.powerCurve
member.summary: This is evaluated and the result used as multiplier for the chargeRate, if useCurve is set to true.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.raycastOffset
member.para: distance in m from raycast transform to start raycasting, used for parts/terrain

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.resMultForGetInfo
member.summary: a multiplier for the output in the GetInfo call (eg. if charge rate = 2 and reMult = 3, it will show a charge rate of 6 in VAB/SPH but will only charge 2 when launched

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.sunTracking
member.summary: If this value is true, the ElectricCharge calculations will assume the panel is able to allineate itself toward the Sun direction, inasmuch as its pivot permit.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.sunTransform
member.summary: Cache the Sun transform locally, to avoid some computations. This really should have made private.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.temperatureEfficCurve
member.summary: This FloatCurve is evaluated with the current part temperature in Kelvin, and the result used as multiplier with chargeRate.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.timeEfficCurve
member.summary: This floatCurve was perhaps meant to make the panels degrade over time. It is evalued and the result multiplied with chargeRate, but no part specify it and it default to a 'flat curve' returning 1.0.

member.name: F:ModuleDeployableSolarPanel.useCurve
member.summary: If this value is true, the solar panel will evaluate the FloatCurve powerCurve to determine a multiplier for the chargeRate. If, instead, this value is false then chargeRate will be multiplied using the current solar flux normalized against the solar flux at the home body.

member.name: T:ModuleEngines
member.summary: A PartModule that can be configured to behave like many different kinds of engines. All stock propulsion systems except for RCS are implemented through ModuleEngines (or ModuleEnginesFX, which is an extension of this module that can do more).

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.allowRestart
member.para: By default allow restart.
member.remarks: - Whether the engine can be restarted after it was shut down. Defaults to True.

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.allowShutdown
member.para: By default allow shutdown.
member.remarks: - Whether the engine can be shut down at all. Typically set False for solid boosters. Defaults to True.

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.atmChangeFlow
member.para: Atmospheric density will change fuel flow (and thus thrust)

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.atmCurve
member.para: Normally thrust is proportional to density, but we allow tuning. Tuning is especially needed because there's no stratosphere, so temperature keeps decreasing and thus speed of sound keeps decreasing.
member.remarks:
- Used for air-breathing engines, usually together with useAtmCurve, velCurve, and useVelCurve. Defines a thrust curve based on atmospheric pressure. Thrust reduction or increase applied by this curve does not change fuel flow. This means engines using this curve only need one static Isp value inside atmosphereCurve, as fuel efficiency is instead defined by how much thrust you're getting at your current altitude (and airspeed, if also using velCurve).
key = pressure,mandatory thrustMultiplier,mandatory tangentAngleIn,optional tangentAngleOut,optional
Pressure is 0 in space, 1 at kerbin sea level, and can be higher elsewhere.

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.atmCurveIsp
member.para: Same as atmCurve, but changes Isp not flow

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.atmosphereCurve
member.para: a curve to determine loss or gain of thrust due to changes in atmosphere vs vacuum values are based on ISP to ATM Pressure
member.remarks: - Represents the specific impulse (Isp) of the engine as a function of atmospheric pressure. To get the Isp at a certain height h (in meters), use

.
key = pressure,mandatory Isp,mandatory tangentAngleIn,optional tangentAngleOut,optional
Pressure is 0 in space, 1 at kerbin sea level, and can be higher elsewhere.

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.CLAMP

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.clampPropReceived

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.thrustTransforms
member.summary: These transforms store the locations and directions at which the thrust this engine generates is applied to the part. member.name: F:ModuleEngines.useThrustCurve

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.useVelCurve
member.para: If false, we don't use the new velCurve.
member.remarks: - Used for air-breathing engines. Defaults to False, must be set to True to make the engine obey a velCurve.

member.name: F:ModuleEngines.velCurve
member.para: replacement for the existing module's velocityCurve. Note that its x value is Mach, not m/s velocity. High-bypass turbofans will see thrust decrease steadily from static. Low-bypass turbofans and turbojets will see thrust decrease slightly up to about 0.2 Mach then increase steadily until the limit is reached (both in terms of heat, and incoming compression vs compressor compression). Ramjets have 0 static thrust, and do not light until 0.3 Mach or so, but once lit have steadily increasing thrust until Mach 5, when the incoming air can no longer be slowed to subsonic (combustion must be subsonic for ramjets). Thermal limits also apply, of course. For heat limits, see machLimit, below.
member.remarks:
- Used for air-breathing engines, usually together with useAtmCurve, atmCurve, and useVelCurve. Defines a thrust curve based on mach number. Thrust reduction or increase applied by this curve does not change fuel flow, which has similar implications on Isp as atmCurve does.
key = machNumber,mandatory thrustMultiplier,mandatory tangentAngleIn,optional tangentAngleOut,optional

member.para: Same as velCurve but changes Isp not flow

member.name: M:ModuleEngines.ModifyFlow
member.para: Returns a multiplier to fuel flow (and thus thrust). Will only do so if atmChangeFlow is true (in which case flow is modified by atmsopheric density, either linearly or via a curve, that's toggled by useAtmCurve) and/or if useVelCurve is true, in which case it's modified by mach finally, it's clamped to CLAMP so it never quite goes to 0. If neither situation obtains, we just return 1.0.

<simplesect kind='return'>
fuel flow multiplier</simplesect>
< First get density (normalized to 1.0 = sea level)

member.name: T:Orbit
member.para: An Orbit class represents a Keplerian orbit. Each Vessel and each CelestialBody has an Orbit. CelestialBodies and on-rails Vessels follow their Orbits exactly. Off-rails vessels (the active vessel and any nearby vessels) do not follow their orbits exactly; instead their motion is computed frame-by-frame from the forces acting on them.
A patched consics trajectory consists of a series of Orbits, called patches.

This class uses multiple axes and reference frames to describe positions and velocities.
We call the choices of axes
World: world coordinates. Left-handed.
member.remarks: We use the concise notation {Axes, Frame} for describing the reference frame and axes used.</para>

member.name: F:Orbit.activePatch
member.summary: Whether this patch actually represents a real orbit patch in the projected flight path. Often Orbit.nextPatch for the last real will not be null, but will be some sort of bogus Orbit object. You can recognize these because activePatch will be false.

member.name: F:Orbit.altitude
member.para: (distance from surface)

member.name: F:Orbit.argumentOfPeriapsis
member.summary: The angle between the ascending node and the periapsis, in degrees.

member.name: F:Orbit.eccentricAnomaly
member.summary: A quantity used in the math describing Keplerian orbits; Google it.

member.name: F:Orbit.eccentricity
member.summary: The eccentricity of the orbit.

member.name: F:Orbit.eccVec
member.summary: A vector that points toward periapsis, with mangitude equal to the eccentricity. NOTE: All Vector3d's returned by Orbit class functions have their y and z axes flipped. You have to flip these back to get the vectors in world coordinates.

member.name: F:Orbit.EndUT
member.summary: The universal time at which this patch ends.

member.name: F:Orbit.epoch
member.summary: A special UT at which the parameters of the Orbit are defined. See meanAnomalyAtEpoch.

member.name: F:Orbit.h
member.summary: The specific orbital angular momentum

member.name: F:Orbit.inclination
member.summary: The inclination of this orbit with respect to the equator of the central body in degrees

member.name: F:Orbit.LAN
member.summary: The longitude of the ascending node of the orbit, in degrees. The LAN is the angle between the ascending node and Planetarium.right, as viewed along Planetarium.up.

member.name: F:Orbit.meanAnomaly
member.summary: Mean anomaly is the fraction of the orbit that has been completed, measured starting from the periapsis, multiplied by 2. Look it up.

member.name: F:Orbit.meanAnomalyAtEpoch
member.summary: The mean anomaly of the orbit at the special UT given by Orbit.epoch.

member.name: F:Orbit.objectType
member.para: secondary parameters

member.name: F:Orbit.ObT
member.para: time on this orbit (since periapsis)
member.remarks: - Time since periapsis, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.ObTAtEpoch
member.summary: The value of ObT at the universal time given by epoch.

member.name: F:Orbit.OrbitFrame
member.para: dynamic parameters

member.name: F:Orbit.orbitPercent
member.para: orbit completion
member.remarks: - Equal to

member.name: F:Orbit.patchEndTransition
member.summary: How the next patch follows onto this one, or FINAL if there is no patch after this one.

member.name: F:Orbit.period
member.summary: The period of the orbit, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.pos
member.summary: The position of the orbiting object, {AliceWorld, Primary}.

member.name: F:Orbit.referenceBody
member.para: keplerian parameters
member.remarks: - The body orbited.

member.name: F:Orbit.secondaryPosAtTransition2
member.para: UT for closest approach to target, if any.

member.name: F:Orbit.semiMajorAxis
member.summary: The semi-major axis of the orbit, in meters. Equal to (PeR + ApR)/2

member.name: F:Orbit.timeToAp
member.summary: The time until the object will reach apoapsis, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.timeToPe
member.summary: The time unti lthe object will reach periapsis, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.vel
member.summary: The velocity of the orbiting object, {AliceWorld, Primary}.

member.name: F:Orbit.Deg2Rad
member.para: orbit frame in fixed space (LAN=0 points along X-axis)

member.summary: The apoapsis of the orbit in meters, measured from sea level.

member.summary: The apoapsis of the orbit in meters, measured from the center of the main body.

member.name: M:Orbit.PeApIntersects(Orbit,Orbit,System.Double)
member.para: Tests two orbits to see if they stand any chance of encounter based on their apoapsis and periapsis distances This is the first-stage test. If a pair fails this, it can be ruled out already as the orbits will never meet. Both orbits need to share the same reference body.
<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>primary</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>The primary orbit
member.remarks: </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> <parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>secondary</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>The secondary orbit</para></parameterdescription> </parameteritem> <parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>threshold</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>The minimum distance to pass the test (should be higher or equal to the SOI radius or either orbit, if available)</para></parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist> <simplesect kind='return'><para>true if the pair passes the test (and needs further verification), false if ruled out.</para></simplesect> </para> -

member.name: M:OrbitDriver.RecalculateOrbit(CelestialBody)
member.para: < Unlike scenarios (progress, contracts, etc), modules won't respond if unloaded. <ref refid='class_module_trip_logger' kindref='compound'>ModuleTripLogger</ref> needs to recognize this event.

member.name: M:OrbitDriver.TrackRigidbody(CelestialBody,System.Double)
member.para: This method updates keplerian parameters from given vessel's position and velocity in worldspace with respect to the reference body. It can also be passed a refbody which is <emphasis>not</emphasis> the current referenceBody; this is for calculating new keplerian parameters when changing frames of reference. NOTE: This normally runs before PhysX integration, which means before our current velocity is applied to our position. However, when on rails, we are pushing a new position and velocity and so when <ref refid='class_orbit_driver' kindref='compound'>OrbitDriver</ref> is running they are correct for the given UT. <ref refid='class_vessel_precalculate' kindref='compound'>VesselPrecalculate</ref> will also at times run this <emphasis>after</emphasis> PhysX integration runs (i.e. it will run this on its Update, and then <emphasis>not</emphasis> run it on the following fixed frame). So we need to decide: Are we computing our orbit pre-integration or post? If we are computing pre-integration, we need to use the last frame's timestamp when passing our position and velocity in.

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>refBody</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>the ref body to compute against (may not be current referenceBody)
member.remarks: </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> <parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>fdtOffset</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> <para>the offset to the current UT to apply when computing the orbit. Per above this may be (last frame UT - this frame UT) since the pos and vel are from the last frame's UT during integration</para></parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist> </para> <para>< convert the rigidbody vectors into the proper coordinate space (Z-up, centered at reference body)</para><para>< orbital pos wrt old reference body</para><para>< our pos and vel in this case are not set until</para><para>< convert from rot to inertial </para>

member.name: T:Part
member.summary: Each part on a vessel is represented by a Part object. Plugins can add new functionality to parts by defining new PartModules, which can then be added to Parts. It is also possible to define new subclasses of Part, but this is deprecated in favor of PartModules.

member.name: F:Part.ActivatesEvenIfDisconnected
member.summary: Whether this part will actually activate if it is scheduled to be activated in the same stage as it is decoupled from the rocket. In particular, sepratrons must have ActivatesEvenIfDisconnected set to true if they are to function properly.

member.name: F:Part.airlock
member.para: noAutoEVAAny disables auto EVA always, whereas noAutoEVAMulti allows it if there is only one part on the vessel.

member.name: F:Part.atmDensity
member.para: 1.0+ thermo

member.name: F:Part.attached
member.para: Flag for whether the part is directly attached to another (it's not the same as parent != null because this is also true for root parts)

member.name: F:Part.attachMode
member.summary: Whether this part is attached to its parent via a stack AttachNode or a surface AttachNode.

member.name: F:Part.attachNodes
member.summary: An AttachNode represents the link between two attached parts. attachNodes is a list of possible nodes to which other parts can be attached to this part. You can find the parts that actually are attached using AttachNode.attachedPart.

member.name: F:Part.children
member.summary: The parts that are children of this part in the part tree (parts that were attached to this part in the editor after this part was already part of the vessel).

member.name: F:Part.compund
member.para: Flag for whether the part is able to attach to another

member.name: F:Part.craftID
member.para: a unique id used in the editor. Defaults to object instance id or loaded from craft data. Will not be reliable after docking

member.name: F:Part.CrewCapacity
member.summary: How many crew members this part can fit.

member.name: F:Part.crossfeedPartSet
member.para: set by the vessel!

member.name: F:Part.customPartData
member.para: A string for saving and loading custom part data. (Do not use linebreaks here. If storing multiple values, separate them with a semicolon

member.name: F:Part.dockingPorts
member.para: original position and rotation, in relation to the vessel. This is set by the vessel when it's first initialized

member.name: F:Part.dragModel
member.summary: Unused?

member.name: F:Part.emissiveConstant
member.summary:
Defines how quickly heat is radiated into space from this part's skin through blackbody radiation, depending on its skin temperature. Conversely, in high ambient heat conditions, defines how quickly the part ingests ambient heat through its skin.
A value of 1.0 would be a perfect blackbody, which (realistically speaking) is physically impossible to achieve - as is any value higher than 1.0. However, the game does let you set values higher than 1.0, if you want.
Default is 0.7.

member.name: F:Part.flightID
member.para: a unique id to identify this part in flight. This one is guaranteed to be unique for all parts in the simulation. Not assigned in the editor.
member.remarks: - A unique identifider for this part. Note that despite the name, each part on the same vessel will still have a different value in this field. This value is persistent and not affected by game load or docking/undocking or similar. This is the 'uid' value at the PART level of the persistent.sfs file.

member.name: F:Part.fuelCrossFeed
member.summary: Whether this part allows fuel crossfeed.

member.name: F:Part.fuelLookupTargets
member.summary: In the flight scene, fuelLookupTargets is the list of fuel lines through which this part can draw fuel. Also if this part is a docking node docked to a another docking node through which it can draw fuel, then the attached docking node will also be in fuelLookupTargets.

member.name: F:Part.gExplodeChance
member.para: Chance per second, i.e. multiplied by fixedDeltaTime

member.name: F:Part.gTolerance
member.summary: G tolerance of this part

member.name: F:Part.heatConductivity
member.summary:
Defines how easily heat conducts between this part's internals and the internals of parts directly attached to it. Default is 0.12; higher numbers mean more conduction. This field does not affect the thermal properties of a part's skin in any way (see skinSkinConductionMult).
Note that conductivity is further modified by the bulkheadProfiles field. Also, conduction is always between two parts, which means that the other part's heatConductivity and bulkheadProfiles also play a role in determining the total flux.

member.name: F:Part.heatConvectiveConstant
member.summary: Defines how easily heat is exchanged between the part's skin and surrounding air or liquid - cooling during slow flight/swim, or heating during atmospheric reentry. Default is unknown. No stock parts explicitly set this field in their configs, not even radiators or heatshields.

member.name: F:Part.inverseStage
member.summary: The stage in which this part will activate, as shown in the staging display. (Possibly called inverseStage because the stages in KSP count down instead of up).

member.name: F:Part.inverseStageCarryover
member.para: True when this inverseStage index should carry over to non-stageable parts.

member.name: F:Part.isControlSource
member.para: Flag for whether this part can provide input to the vessel. (tweaked by command modules)
physical significance of the part.

member.name: F:Part.isMirrored
member.para: set to true if mirrorVector != Vector3.one

member.name: F:Part.launchID
member.para: another unique number shared by all parts launched together on the same vessel

member.name: F:Part.mass
member.summary: The DRY mass of this part, not including the mass of any resources it contains

member.name: F:Part.maximum_drag
member.summary: The drag coefficient of this part is equal to (total mass) * (maximum_drag)

member.name: F:Part.maxTemp
member.summary: The internal temperature at which this part will explode. If skinMaxTemp is not explicitly set, then maxTemp counts for skin temperature too.

member.name: F:Part.minimum_drag
member.summary: Unused.

member.name: F:Part.missionID
member.para: a unique number shared by all parts launched together on the same vessel
member.remarks: - A unique identifier assigned to the part when the vessel it is a part of is created. All parts on the vessel get the same missionID and it does not change. Splitting a vessel with a decoupler will result with two vessels whose parts have the same missionID. When two vessels spawned seperately dock, each part keeps its original missionID, undocking does not change this field either.

member.name: F:Part.NoCrossFeedNodeKey
member.summary: Specifies the name of a node through which this part will NOT draw resources. See the part.cfg of the stock tricoupler for an example of using this to prevent fuel from flowing backwards.

member.name: F:Part.OnEditorAttach
member.summary: Add a function to this callback and it will be called when your part is attached to another part in the editor.

member.name: F:Part.OnEditorDestroy
member.summary: Add a function to this callback and it will be called when your part is deleted in the editor.

member.name: F:Part.OnEditorDetach
member.summary: Add a function to this callback and it will be called when your part is detached, or is part of a set of parts that are detached, in the editor.

member.name: F:Part.OnJustAboutToBeDestroyed
member.summary: Add a function to this callback and it will be called when your part is about to be destroyed during flight.

member.summary: The parent of this part in the part tree: the part to which this part was attached in the editor.

member.name: F:Part.partInfo
member.summary: Some of the part info that is displayed about this part in the editor.

member.name: F:Part.partName
member.summary: Name of the part in cfg file (may be different in-game)

member.name: F:Part.PermanentGroundContact
member.para: flags if part is always touching the surface, i.e. a launch clamp.

member.name: F:Part.physicalSignificance
member.summary: If physicalSignificance == Part.PhysicalSignificance.NONE, then this part doesn't actually have any physics. In particular, it has no mass, regardless of what its "mass" field is set to, and no drag.

member.name: F:Part.PhysicsSignificance
member.summary: Unused?

member.name: F:Part.presExplodeChance
member.para: Chance per second, i.e. multiplied by fixedDeltaTime

member.name: F:Part.recheckShielding
member.para: This is the local variant of AlwaysRecheckShielding. If this is false, even if AlwaysRecheckShielding is true, we won't recheck shielding.

member.name: F:Part.rescaleFactor
member.para: This is the scale factor that's applied after loading. It rescales the model and any nodes. Use to convert from model space to world space.

member.name: F:Part.resourcePriorityUseParentInverseStage
member.para: If true, instead of our inverseStage, use parent's (if not null) inverseStage when reporting res priority

member.name: F:Part.scaleFactor
member.para: This is the scale factor used in the mesh exporter. Use to convert from 3D scene space to model space.

member.name: F:Part.skinInternalConductionMult
member.summary:
Defines how easily heat conducts between this part's skin and the skin of a part directly attached to it.
Default is probably 1.0 (untested). Higher numbers mean more conduction.

member.name: F:Part.skinMassPerArea
member.summary:
How much of a part's thermal mass is allocated to be skin. Higher numbers result in more skin thermal mass.
Resulting number ingame is heavily dependant on each individual part's model and thermal mass.

member.name: F:Part.skinMaxTemp
member.summary: The skin temperature at which this part will explode. If this field is not explicitly defined, the skin uses maxTemp instead.

member.name: F:Part.skinSkinConductionMult
member.summary:
The skin equivalent of heatConductivity, though this one is a multiplier. Defines how easily heat conducts between this part's skin and the skin of a part directly attached to it.
Default is probably 1.0 (untested). Higher numbers mean more conduction.

member.name: F:Part.skinTemperature
member.summary: The part's current skin temperature in Kelvin. Not a constant - don't set this in a part config file. Use skinMaxTemp instead.

member.name: F:Part.skinToInternalFlux
member.summary: How much heat currently flows between internals and skin. Not a constant - don't set this in a part config file. Use skinInternalConductionMult instead.

member.name: F:Part.skinUnexposedExternalTemp
member.summary: The current ambient temperature around the side of a part which is facing away from the bow shock during reentry, in Kelvin. Not a constant - don't set this in a part config file.

member.name: F:Part.srfAttachNode
member.summary: IF this part is surface-attached to its parent, srfAttachNode is the attach node describing this connection.

member.name: F:Part.stackIcon
member.summary: The sicon shown for this part in the staging display.

member.para: public bool DEBUG = false;

member.name: F:Part.temperature
member.summary: The part's current internal temperature in Kelvin. Not a constant - don't set this in a part config file. Use maxTemp instead.

member.para: Chance per second, i.e. multiplied by fixedDeltaTime

member.para: Do we force a recheck of shielding a frame after <ref refid='class_part_1a5e449c9cf56759803c936b4a81ccaed9' kindref='member'>Start()</ref> finsihes? member.name: M:Part.onPartDetach

member.name: M:Part.onPartExplode
member.para: called when the part explodes.

member.name: M:Part.onPartFixedUpdate
member.para: called on every physics update. use to update passive parts that need to apply forces or use much physics, like winglets or RCS.

member.name: M:Part.onPartLoad
member.para: called only once, when the part is first loaded into the game. Use to create components, and do stuff that only needs to be done once.

member.name: M:Part.onPartStart

member.name: M:Part.onPartUpdate
member.para: Called once per frame. use to update passive parts that don't affect physics, like radiators or solar panels

member.name: M:Part.onStartComplete
member.para: called at the end of the start method in all scenes. In flight, this is after rigidbody initialization.

member.name: T:PartModule

member.para: http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/showthread.php/10296-0-15-code-update-PartModule-KSPField-KSPEvent-ConfigNode-and-PartResource

member.name: F:PartModule.moduleName
member.summary: The name of the partModule as per the Class name in code. Should never be edited.

member.name: P:PartModule.Actions

member.name: P:PartModule.ClassID
member.summary: A hash of

member.name: P:PartModule.ClassName
member.summary: In any subclass of PartModule,
member.remarks: will be the name of the subclass. It gets set by the PartModule loading process.

member.name: P:PartModule.Events
member.summary: A list of KSPEvents, which can be triggered by code or by the user through the part's right-click menu. Generated by KSP from all methods tagged [KSPEvent] within the class in code.

member.name: P:PartModule.Fields
member.summary: A list of the KSPFields which the module loads from the part.cfg file. Generated by KSP from all methods tagged [KSPField] within the class in code.

member.para: Method fires once the module has been added to the part. Use for first time setup. Module will not have loaded fully by this point
member.remarks: - This function gets called only once, during the KSP loading screen. See the Unity documentation on Awake for more information.

member.name: M:PartModule.OnCopy(PartModule)
member.para: Use OnCopy to copy any additional data from the <ref refid='class_part_module' kindref='compound'>PartModule</ref> provided

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>fromModule</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist>

member.name: M:PartModule.OnFixedUpdate
member.para: Called every physics/fixed frame that the part is active
member.remarks: - This function gets called once every Unity FixedUpdate cycle (once per physics frame) once the part has been activated (staged). If you want to be called even if the part has not been activated, define a function called

instead of overriding OnFixedUpdate See the Unity documentation on FixedUpdate for more information. You can get the time between FixedUpdates from TimeWarp.fixedDeltaTime. Do any physics stuff in OnFixedUpdate, not OnUpdate.

member.name: M:PartModule.OnIconCreate
member.para: Method fires just before components are stripped from the gameobject to make it an icon. (The part is instantiated and then various components like <ref refid='class_part' kindref='compound'>Part</ref>, <ref refid='class_part_module' kindref='compound'>PartModule</ref>, <ref refid='class_effect_behaviour' kindref='compound'>EffectBehaviour</ref>, Colliders, Particles, etc are stripped and then it's set as the icon prefab. This lets PartModules do stuff to the model right before that happens.

member.name: M:PartModule.OnInactive
member.para: Called before the part goes inactive (after packing etc)
member.remarks: - When does this get called?

member.name: M:PartModule.OnInitialize
member.para: Called on all modules after all parts are loaded but before they give the ship to the game

member.name: M:PartModule.OnLoad(ConfigNode)
member.para: Use OnLoad to load any additional data from the <ref refid='class_config_node' kindref='compound'>ConfigNode</ref> provided

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>node</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist>
member.remarks: - This function is called to initialize the part. The ConfigNode contains the parameters of the module as specified in the part.cfg file, or as you last saved them in OnSave.
member.param: A ConfigNode containing the module's parameters from part.cfg or persistent.sfs

member.name: M:PartModule.OnSave(ConfigNode)
member.para: Use OnSave to serialize additional module information into the <ref refid='class_config_node' kindref='compound'>ConfigNode</ref> provided

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>node</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist>
member.remarks: - This function is called when the game is saved to let the part save persistent data. Add any data you want to persist to the ConfigNode. The ConfigNode will then be saved as part of persistent.sfs. When the game is resumed, you can then read this data back out in OnLoad.

member.name: M:PartModule.OnStart(PartModule+StartState)
member.para: Called when the part starts. The StartState gives an indication of where in flight you are. All values may not be plugged in!

<parameterlist kind='param'><parameteritem> <parameternamelist> <parametername>state</parametername> </parameternamelist> <parameterdescription> </parameterdescription> </parameteritem> </parameterlist>
member.remarks:
- Called when the flight starts, or when the part is created in the editor. OnStart will be called before OnUpdate or OnFixedUpdate are ever called.
Caution: Depending on which scene you are moving to/from, this method may be called before or after OnLoad, be careful of your data handling.
member.param: Some information about what situation the vessel is starting in.

member.name: T:PartResourceDefinition
member.summary:
A PartResourceDefinition contains the basic information defining a type of resource.
It is used by opening a RESOURCE_DEFINITION { } top level node in a config file.

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.density
member.summary: The mass of this resource, per "unit". This is not necessarily per unit volume, as resources don't have defined volumes. Instead resource "density" is the mass of one of this resource.

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.id
member.summary: The integer ID of this resource type.

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.isTweakable
member.summary: Whether or not the player can change in the editor how much of this resource is pre-loaded into a part. (E.g. adding ore to ore tanks which by default start empty.)

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.isVisible
member.summary: Whether or not this resource is visible in the rightclick menu of the part at any time.

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.name
member.summary: The string ID of this resource type. It is the thing you use everywhere else to identify this specific resource.

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.resourceFlowMode
member.summary: How this resource does or does not flow between parts on a ship in response to resource requests by engines and the like.

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.resourceTransferMode
member.summary: How this resource does or does not flow when using the resource transfer function?

member.name: P:PartResourceDefinition.volume
member.summary: Not used by stock KSP as of yet (see density), but present for modding support.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXDensityExponent1
member.summary: One of four variables involved in calculating how much air density is required to get aero effects. (scalar1 * density^exponent1 + scalar2 * density^exponent2). Before messing with this one, play with AeroFXDensityFadeStart and AeroFXVelocityExponent first, and see if you can get your desired effect that way. It's way less complicated.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXDensityExponent2
member.summary: See AeroFXDensityExponent1.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXDensityFadeStart
member.summary: The smaller this number is, the less air density is required for reentry FX to play (starts further up in the atmosphere). Change by orders of magnitude to see a visible difference.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXDensityScalar1
member.summary: See AeroFXDensityExponent1.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXDensityScalar2
member.summary: See AeroFXDensityExponent1.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXFullThermalFX
member.summary: The speed (as a mach number) at which condensation X (white stuff) finishes changing into plasma FX (red stuff). Increasing this will make planes less likely to be sheathed in fire during high-speed flight... but reentering spacecraft lose their plasma trail higher up.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXMachFXFadeEnd
member.summary: Below this air density, you can never get any condensation FX (white stuff). You can still get plasma FX (red stuff); which is unaffected.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXMachFXFadeStart
member.summary: Below this air density, condensation FX (white stuff) will begin to fade out. But only if it is still playing. Plasma FX (red stuff) is unaffected.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXStartThermalFX
member.summary: The speed (as a mach number) at which condensation X (white stuff) starts changing into plasma FX (red stuff). Increasing this will make planes less likely to be sheathed in fire during high-speed flight... but reentering spacecraft lose their plasma trail higher up.

member.name: P:PhysicsGlobals.AeroFXVelocityExponent
member.summary: The higher this number is, the less speed is required is required for reentry FX to show up. This is how KSP fudges a plasma trail into existence at the slow orbital velocities around its downsized planets. For upscaled planets, reduce this number. It is very sensitive - small changes have a major impact.

member.name: P:Planetarium.forward
member.summary: Along with "up" and "right," one of the three vectors defining the fixed celestial reference frame.

member.name: P:Planetarium.right
member.summary: Along with "up" and "forward," one of the three vectors defining the fixed celestial reference frame. The LAN (longitude of the ascending node) of every orbit is defined in reference to Planetarium.right. Specifically, the LAN is the angle between Planetarium.right and the orbit's ascending node, as viewed along Planetarium.up.

member.name: P:Planetarium.up
member.summary: Along with "right" and "forward," one of the three vectors defining the fixed celestial reference frame. As of 0.23.5, all planet rotation axes are aligned with Planetarium.up.

member.para: Adds the given amount of <ref refid='class_reputation' kindref='compound'>Reputation</ref>. member.name: M:ResearchAndDevelopment.GetSubjectValue(System.Single,ScienceSubject)
member.para: Returns the scientific value of a subject for the given amount of science done in it. Does not actually modify the subject's value. Use for previewing devaluation and such.
member.remarks: - A value from 0 to 1, indicating the fraction of "undiscovered" science for that subject that remains to be discovered. For example, in a fresh career where no science has been gathered yet, all subjects will return 1. A subject that has been completely "mined out" will return 0. The subjectScience parameter indicates how much science has already been acquired for that subject. The subject parameter provides the information about science cap (i.e. what's the max possible science obtainable for that subject).

Returns TRUE if ap has been purchased, OR if ap has been marked as "experimental". This happens automatically by default as "No Entry Purchase Required on Research" (PartUpgradesInCareer in persistent.sfs) is enabled, which effectively purchases all parts whenever a tech-level is unlocked.
See also: IsExperimentalPart(), PartTechAvailable(), AddExperimentalPart(), RemoveExperimentalPart()

member.name: T:ScenarioCreationOptions
member.summary: A list of options for use with the KSPScenario attribute.

member.name: T:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects
member.summary: Stores information on asteroid spawning Executed while in Flight, Tracking Station, and Space Center scenes The module schedules periodic "spawn checks" while the game clock is running, at an interval set by spawnInterval. At each spawn check, any asteroids that have gone untracked for too long are removed from the game. To add an element of randomness, only a fraction of checks (controlled by spawnOddsAgainst) have a chance to produce asteroids. No asteroids are produced if the number of untracked asteroids already in the game exceeds spawnGroupMaxLimit. Because spawn checks happen very frequently, the number of detected asteroids in a game where the player never tracks an asteroid will almost always be close to spawnGroupMaxLimit.

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.maxUntrackedLifetime
member.summary: Longest time an asteroid can go untracked before disappearing, in Earth days

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.minUntrackedLifetime
member.summary: Shortest time an asteroid can go untracked before disappearing, in Earth days

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.sizeCurve
member.summary: Sets size distribution for asteroids The output range of [0, 1) is divided equally among the classes. So [0, 0.2) is class A, [0.2, 0.4) is class B, ..., [0.8, 1) is class E. Default curve translates to 12% class A, 13% class B, 49% class C, 13% class D, and 12% class E

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnGroupMaxLimit
member.summary: Number of untracked asteroids at which spawn rate stops completely

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnGroupMinLimit
member.summary: Number of untracked asteroids at which spawn rate begins to slow

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnInterval
member.summary: Number of seconds between asteroid checks These are approximately seconds of in-game time, but if you make sudden changes in the time warp rate the spawner may need some time to catch up. Since asteroids are removed during spawn checks, spawnInterval also controls the asteroid removal rate.

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnOddsAgainst
member.summary: Controls the fraction of spawn checks in which new asteroids are generated The probability of spawning an asteroid is 1 / (1 + spawnOddsAgainst)

member.name: M:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.debugSpawnProbability
member.summary: Returns a description of the current spawn interval and spawn odds

member.name: M:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.SpawnAsteroid
member.summary: Creates a random asteroid and Kerbin-intercepting orbit

member.name: M:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.SpawnLastAsteroid
member.summary: Creates a random asteroid and Kerbin-intercepting orbit.
member.remarks: Asteroid is identical to the last call of SpawnAsteroid()</seealso> Intended for debugging?

member.summary: The available physics warp rates. In 0.18.2 these are {1, 2, 3, 4} by default. You can modify the available rates by modifying this array.

member.summary: The available regular warp rates. In 0.18.2 these are {1, 5, 10, 50, 100, 1000, 10000, 100000} by default. You can modify the available rates by modifying this array.

member.summary: Use this TimeWarp instance to access non-static members.

member.name: P:TimeWarp.CurrentRate
member.summary: The current warp rate, e.g. 50 if the current warp rate is 50x. This number may not be equal to one of the entries in warpRates, because KSP will smoothly interpolate between two warp rates over a period of time when you increase or decrease the warp.

member.name: P:TimeWarp.CurrentRateIndex
member.summary: The index of the current current warp rate in either warpRates or physicsWarpRates, depending on whether WarpMode is HIGH or LOW. Note that CurrentRate may not equal the warp rate indexed by CurrentRateIndex if KSP has not finished interpolating the last warp change.

member.name: P:TimeWarp.fixedDeltaTime
member.summary: The time between FixedUpdate cycles (i.e., the time between physics steps). See the Unity FixedUpdate documentation for more details.

member.name: P:TimeWarp.WarpMode

member.summary: Changes the warp rate to either warpRates[rateIndex] or physicsWarpRates[rate_index], depending on whether WarpMode is HIGH or LOW.
member.param: The index of the desired new warp rate
If false, KSP will gradually smoothly adjust the warp rate up or down until it reaches the target. If true, the warp rate will change instantly.

member.name: T:TutorialScenario
member.summary: A TutorialScenario is a ScenarioModule with some added features that are useful for building tutorials or similar kinds of scenarios. A TutorialScenario comes with a builtin in finite state machine for running the scenario and displays "tutorial pages" in a GUI window alongside a picture of a friendly Kerbal instructor. You can take advantage of all these features by making your ScenarioModule a subclass of TutorialScenario. See HarvesteR's example code in his forum article: http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/content.php/121-Writing-Tutorials-A-Demo-%28and-some-source-code%29

member.name: F:TutorialScenario.instructor
member.summary: Controls the animated image of the kerbal instructor. This object lets you make the instructor run various animations .

member.name: F:TutorialScenario.instructorPrefabName
member.summary: Set this string in OnAssetSetup to specify which instructor kerbal will appear in the tutorial window. The value "Instructor_Gene" gives Gene Kerman as the instructor. The default if you do not specify anything is Werner von Kerman.

member.name: F:TutorialScenario.Tutorial
member.summary: The finite state machine that controls the progression of the tutorial.

member.name: T:UI_Scene
member.summary:
This enum value controls where (i.e. in which game scene) a given action takes place.
Example: UI fields on part modules (such as UI_Toggle) have a property, affectSymCounterparts, that determine "if this UI action happens, should it affect all the symmetry counterparts of the part where the action took place?" The UI_Scene decides where that would happen.

member.name: T:Vessel
member.para: Vessels define individual ships in flight. They work essentially as a header for the set of parts that make up the ship.
member.remarks: - A Vessel object represents a single vessel. Parts that break off from a vessel become their own Vessels. Vessels that merge via docking become one Vessel.

member.summary: This is a kind of time-averaged acceleration. What you probably want instead is acceleration_immediate.

member.summary: The acceleration of the vessel, in m/s^2.

member.name: F:Vessel.heightFromTerrain
member.summary: The vertical distance in meters between the vessel and the nearest terrain (including buildings), or -1 when sea depth is greater than 600m (terrainAltitude <= -600). Once you are above roughly 42km above ground it turns to -1 again (only confirmed on Kerbin so far)

member.name: F:Vessel.horizontalSrfSpeed
member.summary: Presumably, the horizontal component of srf_velocity, in m/s.

member.name: F:Vessel.id
member.para: Unique identifier for each vessel.
member.remarks: - A unique identifier assigned to a vessel. When two vessels dock, the combined vessel has the id of the vessel docked to. On undock, the vessel undocked from keeps its id, the vessel that undocks gets a new id. Note that this id is always fresh, a vessel gets a different id when it undocks then it had before docking. This is the pid value in the persistent.sfs at the VESSEL level.

member.name: F:Vessel.obt_speed
member.summary:
Presumably obt_velocity.magnitude.
Vessel.obt_velocity and .srf_velocity and the spd versions are not valid in FixedUpdate unless on rails. This is because they are based off what the orbit is estimated to be after PhysX integration runs (i.e. after all FixedUpdates run). (From http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/147576-modders-notes-for-ksp-12/)

member.name: F:Vessel.obt_velocity
member.summary:
The current velocity of the vessel, in world coordinates, in the nonrotating inertial reference frame.
Vessel.obt_velocity and .srf_velocity and the spd versions are not valid in FixedUpdate unless on rails. This is because they are based off what the orbit is estimated to be after PhysX integration runs (i.e. after all FixedUpdates run). (From http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/147576-modders-notes-for-ksp-12/)

member.name: F:Vessel.OnFlyByWire
member.para: pass the control state from the scene handler to this vessel.
member.remarks: - You can add your own function to this callback to register a function that can provide flight control input to the vessel. Once you've registered this callback, it will be called once per FixedUpdate. Provide flight control input by modifying the FlightCtrlState passed to your function. This FlightCtrlState will already contain the player's input, which you can modify or override as desired.
member.example: void MyAutopilotFunction(FlightCtrlState s) { s.yaw = 1; } ... vessel.OnFlyByWire += MyAutopilotFunctionThis will create an autopilot that always yaws hard to the right. You can probably devise something more useful, though...

member.name: F:Vessel.OnJustAboutToBeDestroyed
member.summary: You can add a function to this callback, and the function will be called when the vessel is "just about to be destroyed."

member.name: F:Vessel.orbitDriver
member.summary: This is the 'parent' container for everything to do with the vessels orbit, use OrbitDriver.orbit to find and set information about the vessel orbit.

member.name: F:Vessel.packed
member.para: landing / splashdown detection
member.remarks: - Whether the vessel is currently packed. Vessels are only packed when the come within about 300m of the active vessel.

member.name: F:Vessel.patchedConicSolver
member.summary: Among other things, the patchedConicSolver stores information about the player's current set of maneuver nodes.

member.name: F:Vessel.pqsAltitude
member.summary: Presumably, the height in meters of the planet's terrain QuadSphere directly under the vessel, compared to sea level. This does not take the height of buildings into account. It is generally within +/- 1m of terrainAltitude, except when over buildings (terrainAltitude does account for buildings) or sea with a depth of greater than 600m (terrainAltitude <= -600, heightFromTerrain == -1).

member.name: F:Vessel.protoVessel
member.summary: The protoVessel can be used to get some saved information about unloaded vessels.

member.name: F:Vessel.referenceTransformId
member.summary: This is the flightID of the part that is the current 'Control from Here' part. This is the root part until changed by the player. The vessel transform is set to the transform of this part. This is the 'ref' value in the persistent.sfs at the VESSEL level.

member.name: F:Vessel.situation

member.name: F:Vessel.specificAcceleration
member.para: Specific acceleration is the vessel's potential acceleration per unit of throttle. Used to estimate burn times and such. NOTE: this value is calculated based on smoothed acceleration, so it isn't completely accurate. It will also change as the vessel's mass is reduced as fuel burns away. (it does get pretty accurate after burning for a few seconds)

member.summary:
Presumably srf_velocity / srf_velocity.magnitude
Vessel.obt_velocity and .srf_velocity and the spd versions are not valid in FixedUpdate unless on rails. This is because they are based off what the orbit is estimated to be after PhysX integration runs (i.e. after all FixedUpdates run). (From http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/147576-modders-notes-for-ksp-12/)

member.name: F:Vessel.srf_velocity
member.summary:
The velocity of the vessel in the "surface" reference frame, the reference frame that rotates with the planet.
Vessel.obt_velocity and .srf_velocity and the spd versions are not valid in FixedUpdate unless on rails. This is because they are based off what the orbit is estimated to be after PhysX integration runs (i.e. after all FixedUpdates run). (From http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/147576-modders-notes-for-ksp-12/)

member.name: M:Vessel.SetLandedAt(string,UnityEngine.GameObject,string)
member.para: Set the LandedAt and displaylandedAt variables. an optional GameObject and an optional inputdisplaylandedAt string can be passed in. The landedAt field will be set to the passed in landedAt string. If an inputdisplaylandedAt string is passed in then the displaylandedAt string is set to this string (Usually localized language). If the inputdisplaylandedAt is empty and a GameObject is supplied the GameObject Unity Tag will be used to lookup a <ref refid='class_mini_biome' kindref='compound'>MiniBiome</ref> name. If no inputdisplaylandedAt or GameObject are passed in the displaylandedAt field is set to the landedAt field.

member.name: T:VesselRanges
member.summary: VesselRanges are used to store the distance at which the Vessel changes to a other state. A small example:
member.remarks: the code change the load distance of v to 10 (meters?) as long as v is in the situation 'landed'. If v is in orbit the load distance
is effective. to avoid unknown behavior make the following relation sure:
